page.title: Welcome to CS101!
page.text: Welcome to \dred{Introduction to Programming}!
CS101: \begin{itemize} \item 12 sections \item 3 lecturers \item 6 lead TAs \item about 38 helper TAs \end{itemize}
Each section has one 3-hour lab per week. This is the most important part of the course!
You must regularly check the course announcements on \dred{http://cs101.kaist.ac.kr}

page.title: Grading
Text book
page.text: \dred{Practical Programming: An Introduction to Computer Science Using Python} by Jennifer Campbell, Paul Gries, Jason Montojo, and Greg Wilson. Pragmatic Programmers, 2009.
Course slides and example code used in the lecture available at \dred{http://tclab.kaist.ac.kr/cs101/slides.html}
Lecture notes on robot programming and photo processing, available at \dred{http://tclab.kaist.ac.kr/cs101/}

page.title: Python
page.text: This course is about \dred{programming} and \dred{computational thinking}, not about learning a programming language.

Python is a programming language that is easy to learn and very powerful. \begin{itemize} \item Used in many universities for introductory courses. \item Main language used for web programming at Google. \item Widely used in scientific computation, for instance at NASA, by mathematicians and physicists. \item Available on embedded platforms, for instance Nokia mobile phones. \item Large portions of games (such as Civilization IV) are written in Python. \end{itemize}
Once you learnt programming in one language, it is relatively easy to learn another language, such as C++ or Java.

page.title: Why are you here?
page.text: Every scientist and engineer must know some programming. It is part of basic education, like calculus, linear algebra, introductory physics and chemistry, or English.

Computer science is not computer programming. We teach programming to teach \dred{computational thinking}: \begin{itemize} \item Solving problems (with a computer). \item Thinking on multiple levels of abstraction.\\ Decompose a problem into smaller problems. \item A way of human thinking (\dred{not} ``thinking like a computer'') \item Thinking about recipes (\dred{algorithms}).\\ 30~years ago the solution to a problem in science or engineering was usually a formula. Today it is usually an algorithm (DNA, proteins, chemical reactions, factory planning, logistics). \end{itemize}
Alan Perlis 1961

page.title: What is a program?
page.text: A program is a \dred{sequence of instructions} that solves some problem (or achieves some effect).
For instance: Call your friend on the phone and give her instructions to find your favorite caf\'e. Or explain how to bake a cake.
\dred{Instructions} are operations that the computer can already perform.
But we can define \dred{new instructions} and raise the \dred{level of abstraction}!
A program implements an \dred{algorithm} (a recipe for solving a problem).

page.title: What is debugging?
page.text: A \dred{bug} is a mistake in a program. \dred{Debugging} means to find the mistake and to fix it.
Computer programs are very complex systems. Debugging is similar to an experimental science: You experiment, form hypotheses, and verify them by modifying your program.

page.title: Why is programming useful?
page.text: \item 20~years ago, electrical engineering students learnt about circuits. Today they learn about embedded systems. \item You can build a radio in software. \item Industrial engineers program industrial robots. Moreover, today's industrial engineers work on logistics---problems that can only be solved by computer. \item Modern automobiles contain thousands of lines of code, and would not run without microprocessors. \item Mathematicians gain insight and intuition by experimenting with mathematical structures, even for discrete objects such as groups and graphs. \item Experimental data often needs to be reformatted to be analyzed or reused in different software. Python is fantastic for this purpose. \item Experimental data sets are nowadays too large to be handled manually.

page.title: Why learn programming?
page.text: \item If you can only use software that \dred{someone else} made for you, you limit your ability to achieve what you want. \item For instance, digital media is manipulated by software. If you can only use Photoshop, you limit your ability to express yourself. \item Programming gives you freedom.

page.title: Why is programming fun?
page.text: Programming is a creative process.\\ ~\hfill cf.~freshman design
A single person can actually build a software system of the complexity of the space shuttle hardware. Nothing similar is true in any other discipline.

There is a large and active \dred{open-source community}: people who write software in their free time for fun, and distribute it for free on the internet.\\ For virtually any application there is code available that you can download and modify freely.

page.title: Let's get started
page.text: But now let me show you some Python code\ldots
\item interactive Python \item Python programs (scripts) \item comments \item your own instructions: functions \item keywords

page.title: Adding new functions
page.text: A \dred{function definition} specifies the name of a new function and the sequence of statements that execute when the function is \dred{called}.
keyword
colon
indentation

page.title: Flow of execution
page.text: Execution begins at the first statement. Statements are executed one-by-one, top to bottom.
Function \dred{definitions} do not change the flow of execution---but only \dred{define} a function.
Function \dred{calls} are like \dred{detours} in the flow of execution.
function definitions
function calls

page.title: Robots
page.text: dot notation
How can |hubo| turn right?
Define a function!

page.title: Newspaper delivery
page.text: Hubo should climb the stairs to the front door, drop a newspaper there, and return to his starting point.
Problem outline: \begin{itemize} \item Climb up four stairs \item Drop the newspaper \item Turn around \item Climb down four stairs \end{itemize}
Python version: \begin{V} climb_up_four_stairs() hubo.drop_beeper() turn_around() climb_down_four_stairs() \end{V}

page.title: Implementing the steps
Top-down design
page.text: Start at the top of the problem, and make an outline of a solution.
For each step of this solution, either write code directly, or outline a solution for this step.
When all the partial problems have become so small that we can solve them directly, we are done and the program is finished.

page.title: Simple repetitions
page.text: Don't forget the indentation!
for-loop

page.title: Avoiding repetitions
